files.U.S. Au Pair Program (J-1 Visa).docx:
U.S. Au Pair Program (J-1 Visa)

Overview

The Au Pair Program is a comprehensive cultural exchange experience where the participant becomes a member of an American host family, providing childcare and assisting with some light household duties. In return, the Au Pair receives a weekly stipend, a private room, free meals, health insurance, and the opportunity to attend educational courses at a local college or university.

Program Duration: 12 months (with the possibility of extension up to 24 months).

Target Group: Young men and women between the ages of 18 and 26.

Permitted Activities

Childcare (feeding, helping with homework, accompanying them to school or activities).

Assisting with household chores related to the children (tidying their rooms, washing their clothes).

Participating in the daily life of the family as an essential resident.

âš ï¸ Not permitted to perform heavy household duties or work outside the scope of the host family agreement.

Essential Requirements

Age between 18 and 26 years old.

English proficiency at a level enabling communication with the family.

At least a High School Diploma (General Secondary Certificate).

Proven experience in childcare (caring for siblings, volunteer work, daycare experience).

Passing an English language personal interview with the sponsoring agency.

Passing a medical exam and having a clean criminal background check.

Benefits

Weekly stipend (approximately $195 â€“ $215 USD minimum).

Free room and board with the host family.

Mandatory health insurance for the entire program duration.

Educational stipend (up to $500 annually for academic courses).

Paid vacation (two weeks annually).

30 additional days after the program ends for travel within the U.S.

Program Objectives

Promoting cultural exchange by integrating participants into the daily life of an American family.

Providing reliable childcare for American families.

Offering young adults an educational opportunity through academic courses.

Developing personal skills such as independence, leadership, and communication.

Key Program Features

Combines work, study, and cultural exchange.

Low living costs because accommodation and food are free.

An ideal opportunity for Jordanian and Arab youth to gain life and educational experience in a safe environment.

Step-by-Step Application Process

Register with an Accredited Au Pair Sponsor: Create your profile, complete an initial interview, and begin the host family matching process.

Obtain Host Family Acceptance via the Sponsor: Sign the agreement and finalize your program plan.

Receive Form DS-2019 from the Sponsor: The primary document for the visa application.

Pay the SEVIS I-901 Fee: Under the BridgeUSA program for the Au Pair category.

Complete the Electronic DS-160 Form: And attach the photo according to specifications.

Book the U.S. Embassy Appointment: Prepare for the interview and gather supporting documents.

Attend the Interview and Complete Biometrics: Answer questions about your role, responsibilities, and ability to adapt culturally and domestically.

Receive the Visa and Arrange Travel: The sponsor coordinates reception, orientation training, and details with the family.

Required Documents

Valid Passport: Must be valid for at least six months beyond your stay.

Biometric Personal Photo: 51x51 mm (5x5 cm) with a light background, as per Embassy standards.

DS-160 Form: Electronic Non-immigrant Visa Application.

DS-2019 Form: Issued by the accredited sponsor, proving acceptance into the Au Pair program.

Proof of Fee Payment: Visa fee receipt and SEVIS I-901 receipt.

Host Family Agreement: Invitation letter/contract between you and the family via the sponsor.

Eligibility Evidence: Documented childcare experience, clean medical and criminal background check, and appropriate English language level.

Detailed Costs and Fees

Visa Fee: USD 185, payable upon submission of DS-160.

SEVIS I-901 Fee: USD 35 for the Au Pair category under BridgeUSA.

Sponsor/Agency Fees: Vary depending on the agency, usually between USD 1,000â€“2,000, covering matching, issuance, and support. Always check each sponsorâ€™s details before committing.

Potential Additional Costs:

Round-trip international airfare

Medical exam, criminal background check, and document translation if required

Health insurance if not fully covered by the sponsor

Financial and Educational Benefits Typically Included:

Weekly stipend within the nationally approved minimum for the Au Pair program

Private room + free meals with the host family

Educational allowance up to USD 500 per year for locally accredited courses (These elements are arranged through the sponsor and host family and specified in the agreement.)

What Kaya Offers You

Selection of the Best Sponsor and Family: We evaluate sponsor reputation, conditions, and support offered, recommending the best fit for your circumstances.

Professional Profile Preparation: CV focused on childcare, reliable reference letters, and documented experience in an organized manner.

Document and Appointment Management: From DS-2019 and DS-160 to SEVIS and the consular appointmentâ€”every step with precise timing and a ready checklist.

Embassy Interview Training: Mock consular questions, clarifying your role and responsibilities, and how to highlight your cultural and linguistic readiness.

Pre-Departure Orientation: Practical guide to communicating with the family, professional boundaries, basic first aid, and American home culture.

Post-Arrival Support: Follow-up during the first 90 days, emergency contacts, and guidance for enrolling in local educational courses.

Start your journey as a member of an American family and gain invaluable life and educational experience â€” Register now with Kaya and let your future begin here.

files.U.S. International Visitor Program (J-1:
U.S. International Visitor Program (J-1 Visa)

Overview

The International Visitor Leadership Program (IVLP) is the flagship initiative within the International Visitor category. It is managed by the U.S. Department of State and is considered a cultural diplomacy tool to enhance relations between the United States and other countries. It targets emerging leaders, academics, journalists, government officials, and entrepreneurs who are expected to have an impact in their communities.

Program Duration: Typically 2 to 4 weeks.

Nature: Official invitation from the U.S. Department of State (Direct application is not possible).

Goal: Building bridges of understanding and cooperation between peoples.

Permitted Activities

Attending official meetings with American counterparts in government, academia, or the private sector.

Participating in workshops and seminars on specific topics (e.g., education, media, human rights, entrepreneurship).

Conducting field visits to local and national American institutions.

Interacting with American society through cultural and social activities.

Essential Requirements

Participants are selected through nomination by the U.S. Embassy in their country or partner organizations.

No direct individual application is accepted.

The nominee must be an emerging leader or an influential professional in their field.

English proficiency at a level enabling effective communication.

A valid passport.

Application Steps (Nominated Individuals)

Nomination by the U.S. Embassy or a partner organization.

Receive the official invitation letter.

Receive Form DS-2019.

Pay the SEVIS I-901 fee ($220 USD).

Complete the DS-160 form and pay the visa fee ($185 USD).

Book an appointment at the U.S. Embassy.

Attend the interview and submit documents.

Travel to the U.S. and participate in the program.

Required Documents

Visa Application Form (DS-160).

Form DS-2019 issued by the U.S. Department of State.

Visa Fee Receipt ($185 USD).

SEVIS I-901 Fee Receipt ($220 USD).

Recent personal photo (5x5 cm, white background).

Valid Passport.

Official Invitation Letter from the U.S. Department of State.

Costs and Fees

Visa Fee: USD 185

SEVIS I-901 Fee: USD 220

Program Costs: Usually covered by the U.S. government (accommodation, domestic travel, activities)

Potential Additional Costs:

International airfare (sometimes covered by the invitation)

Personal expenses.

Program Objectives

Promoting mutual understanding between the United States and other countries.

Building professional networks between international leaders and their American counterparts.

Exchanging expertise in politics, economics, media, education, health, and other fields.

Empowering emerging leaders to gain new insights and apply them in their home countries.

Benefits for Participants

Opportunity for direct engagement with high-level U.S. institutions.

Building a strong international network.

Enhancing the CV with a prestigious diplomatic and cultural experience.

Rich cultural experience through interaction with American society.

What Kaya Offers You

Preparing your personal profile to be nomination-ready by the Embassy.

Crafting your CV and letters to reflect your leadership and impact.

Training you for the consular interview to ensure you pass with confidence.

Guiding you during the program to maximize benefits from activities and networking.

With Kaya, turn your local leadership into global influence â€” Be part of the J-1 International Visitor Program and start building a global network today.

files.U.S. STEM Initiatives Program (J-1 Visa):
U.S. STEM Initiatives Program (J-1 Visa)

Overview

The Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Initiatives Program (J-1 STEM Initiatives) is a recent initiative under the BridgeUSA programs, launched in partnership with the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP). It aims to expand training and research opportunities for international students and researchers in STEM fields within the United States, primarily through two tracks:

Academic Training STEM Extension.

Early Career STEM Research Initiative.



Program Tracks

1. Academic Training STEM Extension

Target: International undergraduate and master's students in STEM majors.

Benefit: Grants an additional 18-month extension following the initial academic training period.

Duration: The total duration can be up to 36 months (instead of just 18 months for non-Ph.D. holders).

Goal: To enable students to gain in-depth practical experience in U.S. companies or institutions before returning to their home countries.

2. Early Career STEM Research Initiative

Target: Researchers and professionals at the beginning of their careers (Early Career).

Scope: Links U.S. STEM companies and research institutions with international J-1 visitors.

Focus Areas: Offers training and research opportunities in fields such as:

Artificial Intelligence (AI).

Renewable Energy.

Biotechnology.

Cybersecurity.

Duration: Can extend up to 5 years under the Research Scholar or Professor category.

Permitted Activities

Participation in advanced research projects.

Practical training in STEM laboratories or companies.

Collaboration with American researchers in strategic fields.

Attending scientific conferences and workshops.

Essential Requirements

The applicant must be a student or researcher in a STEM field (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics).

Obtaining acceptance from a U.S. institution (university, lab, or company).

Having an accredited Sponsor from the U.S. Department of State.

English proficiency at an academic level.

A valid passport.



Detailed Application Steps for STEM Programs

1. Determine the Right Program

There are several STEM initiatives in the U.S., some at the state level (like the STEM Incentive Program in New York) and others at the university level or through national scholarships like Fulbright or Knight-Hennessy.

Choose whether you are seeking a scholarship, an exchange program, or university admission in a STEM major.

2. Verify Eligibility Requirements

Some programs require applicants to be in the top 10% of their high school class (as in New York).

Other programs require a high academic GPA, English language proficiency (TOEFL or IELTS), and sometimes experience in scientific projects or research activities.

3. Prepare Core Documents

Translated and certified academic certificates.

Language test scores (TOEFL/IELTS) and potentially SAT/ACT for undergraduate studies.

Letters of recommendation from professors or supervisors.

Statement of Purpose outlining your passion for science and technology and how you will benefit from the program.

Academic CV highlighting your scientific or research achievements.

4. Apply via the Official Platform

Most programs have an online application portal.

Upload documents and complete the application form before the deadline.

5. Interviews or Tests (If Required)

Some initiatives may require a personal interview or an additional essay to assess your skills.

6. Receive Acceptance and Funding

After acceptance, you may be required to commit to certain conditions, such as full-time study or working in a STEM field within the U.S. for a specified period (as in state programs).

Required Documents for Visa Application

DS-160 form.

Form DS-2019 from the sponsoring organization.

Visa Fee Receipt ($185 USD).

SEVIS I-901 Fee Receipt ($220 USD).

Recent personal photo (5x5 cm, white background).

Valid Passport.

Acceptance or Invitation Letter from the U.S. institution.

Costs and Fees

Visa Fee: USD 185

SEVIS Fee: USD 220

Sponsor Fees: Vary depending on the organization, usually between USD 1,000â€“2,500

Mandatory Health Insurance: USD 600â€“1,200 annually

Additional Costs:

International airfare

Document translation

Objectives

Boosting global innovation by involving international researchers in U.S. STEM projects.

Supporting American companies by leveraging international talent.

Developing participants' expertise to return to their home countries with added value.

Building long-term global research networks.

Benefits for Participants

Research and practical experience at prestigious U.S. institutions.

Possibility of an extended stay (up to 36 months for students, up to 5 years for researchers).

Academic and professional support that enhances the CV.

Opportunity to build a global professional network.

What Kaya Offers You

Evaluating your academic profile to determine the most suitable track (Academic Training Extension or Early Career Research).

Crafting your CV and letters to meet the requirements of U.S. universities and companies.

Follow-up on all application steps until the visa is issued.

Training you for the consular interview to ensure you pass with confidence.

With Kaya, let your passion for science and technology be your passport to the world â€” Enroll now in the J-1 STEM Initiatives program and start your research journey at the heart of American innovation.

files.U.S. Summer Work Travel Program (J-1 SWT:
U.S. Summer Work Travel Program (J-1 SWT)

Overview

This program offers Jordanian university students the opportunity to live and work in the United States during their summer break. Participants can take temporary jobs in sectors like tourism, hospitality, restaurants, and hotels, and then use the remaining time for travel and exploring American cities and culture. The program's goal is to enhance cultural exchange through integrating students into American society, rather than merely being a means of employment.

Program Duration: Up to 4 months during the summer vacation.

Target Group: Full-time university students enrolled in an accredited university outside the United States.

Permitted Activities

Working in seasonal or temporary jobs such as:

Hotels and Resorts.

Restaurants and CafÃ©s.

Amusement Parks and Recreation areas.

Retail stores.

Traveling within the U.S. after the work period ends (usually up to 30 additional days).

Popular Jobs for Jordanian Students in SWT

Most Jordanian students choose seasonal jobs in the hospitality and tourism sectors, as they are the most in-demand and offer easy integration, along with direct interaction with the American community to improve their English. Prominent jobs include:

Hotels and Resorts: Working in reception, housekeeping, or food service within the hotels.

Restaurants and CafÃ©s: Positions like Host/Hostess, kitchen helper, or customer service.

Theme Parks: Such as Disney and Six Flags, where students operate rides, sell tickets, or assist visitors.

Retail Stores: Assisting with sales or stocking merchandise.

Beach Resorts and Ski Centers: Seasonal jobs related to the tourist season, such as lifeguarding or visitor service.

These jobs do not require advanced experience but rely on the ability to communicate in English, enthusiasm, and flexibility in dealing with customers.

Why is the SWT Program Highly Sought After?

Flexibility: Does not require advanced professional experience; merely requires full-time university enrollment.

Affordable Cost: Compared to other J-1 programs, fees are lower (SEVIS is only $35), and seasonal jobs help the student cover a large portion of their expenses.

Work & Travel Combination: Combines supplementary income in USD with the opportunity to travel within the U.S. after the work period.

English Improvement: Through daily interaction with customers and coworkers.

Rich Cultural Experience: Allows the Jordanian student to experience American life up close and build international friendships.

CV Enhancement: Short-term international work experience adds significant value when applying for jobs or graduate studies.

Benefits for Jordanian Students

Supplementary income in USD to cover travel and living expenses.

English language improvement through daily practice with customers and colleagues.

Rich cultural experience through interaction with people from diverse backgrounds.

Enhancing the CV with international work experience in a professional setting.

Practical Tips for Jordanian Students

Choose the job carefully: Some jobs offer more working hours (like restaurants and hotels), meaning better income.

Plan travel early: Utilize the Grace Period after work ends for travel within the U.S.

Improve your language before traveling: The better your English, the better your chances of getting a superior job and a richer experience.

Be flexible: American employers value students who adapt quickly to the work environment.

Essential Requirements

The applicant must be a full-time university student at an accredited educational institution outside the U.S.

Must have completed at least one academic semester before applying, and preferably have completed 30 credit hours or equivalent.

Proficiency in English at a level enabling communication in a work environment.

Age between 18 and 28 years old (may vary slightly depending on the sponsor; some set the limit at 27).

Must obtain a pre-arranged job offer from a U.S. employer through an accredited sponsor (a licensed intermediary company or organization approved by the U.S. Department of State).

Application Steps

Register through an accredited Sponsor.

Obtain a seasonal job offer in the United States.

Receive Form DS-2019.

Pay the SEVIS I-901 fee ($35 USD).

Complete the DS-160 form and pay the visa fee.

Book an appointment at the U.S. Embassy in Amman.

Attend the interview and submit documents.

Travel to the U.S. and start working.

Required Documents

Visa Application Form (DS-160).

Form DS-2019 issued by the sponsor.

Visa Fee Receipt ($185 USD).

SEVIS I-901 Fee Receipt ($35 USD for the SWT program).

Recent personal photo (5x5 cm, white background).

Valid Passport.

Proof of full-time university enrollment and academic transcript.

Costs and Fees

Visa Fee: USD 185.

SEVIS I-901 Fee: USD 35 (reduced for the Summer Work Travel program).

Program/Sponsor Fees: Vary depending on the organization, usually ranging between USD 1,000 â€“ 2,000.

Additional Costs:

International airfare

Mandatory health insurance

Personal expenses

Benefits for Jordanian Students

Opportunity to work in a real American environment.

Improve English through daily practice.

Experience American culture up close.

Travel within the United States after completing work.

Strengthen your CV with international experience.

What We Offer You at Kaya

Assistance in choosing the most suitable sponsor and job.

Professional preparation of your academic file.

Follow-up on all application steps until the visa is issued.

Training for your personal interview at the embassy.

Turn your summer break into an unforgettable experience with Kaya â€” Register now to start your journey on the J-1 Summer Work Travel program.

files.U.S. Camp Counselor Program (J-1 Visa).d:
U.S. Camp Counselor Program (J-1 Visa)

Overview

The Camp Counselor Program allows university students, graduates, teachers, and youth workers to work at American summer camps as supervisors for educational and recreational activities. The program aims to foster cultural exchange by having participants share their culture and expertise with American children, while in turn learning about American culture in a fun and safe environment.

Program Duration: Typically 8 to 10 weeks during the summer.

Target Group: University students, teachers, or individuals with experience working with children or special skills (sports, arts, music).

Permitted Activities

Supervising children and youth at camps.

Organizing sports, arts, cultural, and musical activities.

Participating in trips and outdoor activities.

Promoting cultural exchange by sharing customs and traditions with the children.

âš ï¸ Participants are not allowed to work as administrators, cooks, or cleaners; their role is strictly limited to supervision and educational/recreational activities.

Essential Requirements

The applicant must be 18 years old or older.

English proficiency at a level enabling effective communication with children and colleagues.

Must be a university student, graduate, teacher, or have experience working with youth.

Possessing special skills (such as sports, arts, music) is an added advantage.

Benefits

Weekly Salary or Stipend equivalent to what American counselors receive (typically $\ge \$2,000$ before tax for the season).

Free accommodation and food for the duration of the program at the camp.

Rich cultural experience from living with an international and American team.

Opportunity to travel within the U.S. after the program ends (usually up to 30 additional days).

Enhancing the CV with international experience in informal education and youth work.

Application Steps

Register through an accredited Sponsor.

Obtain acceptance from a U.S. summer camp.

Receive Form DS-2019.

Pay the SEVIS I-901 fee.

Complete the DS-160 form and pay the visa fee.

Book an appointment at the U.S. Embassy.

Attend the interview and submit documents.

Travel to the U.S. and start the program.

Required Documents

Visa Application Form (DS-160).

Form DS-2019 from the sponsoring organization.

Visa Fee Receipt ($185 USD).

SEVIS I-901 Fee Receipt ($35 USDâ€”reduced for the Camp Counselor program).

Recent personal photo (5x5 cm, white background).

Valid Passport.

Proof of university enrollment or professional experience with youth.

Why is this Program Highly Sought After?

Low Cost: SEVIS fee is only $35, lower than any other J-1 program.

All-Inclusive: Includes free housing and food, significantly reducing expenses.

Fun Environment: A fun, informal environment, away from academic or professional pressure.

Valuable Experience: Ideal opportunity for students and teachers to gain practical experience working with children and youth.

Global Network: A rich social experience allowing for long-lasting international friendships.

Key Program Objectives

Promote Cultural Exchange: Enables participants to share their culture, language, and customs with American children and vice versa, building bridges of understanding.

Develop Personal and Professional Skills: Cultivating skills in leadership, teamwork, and problem-solving, along with practical experience in youth development.

Provide a Safe, Fun Learning Environment: Counselors supervise sports, arts, music, and cultural activities, teaching children values like cooperation and responsibility.

Low-Cost International Professional Experience: The low fees and inclusion of room/board make it financially accessible.

Build a Global Network: Camps host participants from dozens of countries, creating long-term international connections.

Financial Details and Income

Official Fees:

Visa Application Fee: $185 USD.

SEVIS I-901 Fee: $35 USD.

Sponsor Fees: Typically range from $500 â€“ $1,000 USD and cover:

Application processing and DS-2019 issuance.

Mandatory basic health insurance for the program duration.

Support and monitoring in the U.S.

Income and Financial Benefits:

Counselors receive a stipend of at least $2,000 (pre-tax) for an approximate 9-week period.

Free Room and Board throughout the program significantly minimizes daily expenses.

With Kaya, make your summer an unforgettable adventure â€” Register now for the Camp Counselor Program to live an experience full of fun, culture, and new friendships.

files.U.S. Trainee Program (J-1 Visa).docx:
U.S. Trainee Program (J-1 Visa)

Overview

The J-1 Trainee Program aims to enable international professionals to develop their practical skills and learn about American business practices in various fields such as business, management, finance, engineering, IT, tourism and hospitality, media, law, and others. The program is not limited to professional training but also focuses on cultural exchange by integrating trainees into the American workplace and community.

Program Duration: Up to 18 months (except for the hospitality and tourism sector, where the maximum is 12 months).

Target Group: Professionals who have completed their university education and possess practical experience, or those with at least 5 years of practical experience in their field.

Permitted Activities

Practical training in the professional field of specialization.

Participation in professional projects within American companies.

Attending workshops and cultural activities to enhance cultural exchange.

Not permitted to work outside the scope of the training outlined in the program plan (DS-7002).

Essential Requirements

The applicant must be either:

A university graduate from outside the U.S. with at least one year of practical experience in the field of specialization.

Or possess at least 5 years of practical experience in the specialized field, if they do not hold a university degree.

Proficiency in English at a level enabling communication in a work environment.

Obtaining an official training offer from a U.S. company.

Having an accredited Sponsor from the U.S. Department of State to issue Form DS-2019.

A valid passport for the entire duration of the program.

Application Steps

Obtain a training offer from a U.S. company.

Prepare and sign the training plan (DS-7002).

Receive Form DS-2019 from the sponsoring organization.

Pay the SEVIS I-901 fee ($220 USD).

Complete the DS-160 online application form.

Pay the visa fee ($185 USD).

Book an appointment at the U.S. Embassy.

Attend the interview and submit documents.

Required Documents for the Interview

Visa Application Form (DS-160).

Form DS-2019 issued by the sponsor.

Signed Training Plan Form (DS-7002) from the host company.

Visa Fee Receipt ($185 USD).

SEVIS I-901 Fee Receipt ($220 USD).

Recent personal photo (5x5 cm, white background).

Valid Passport.

Academic certificates or professional experience proof confirming eligibility.

Costs and Fees

Visa Application Fee: USD 185.

SEVIS I-901 Fee: USD 220.

Program/Sponsor Fees: Vary depending on the sponsoring organization, usually ranging between USD 1,000 â€“ 2,500.

Potential Additional Costs:

Document shipping

files.U.S. Intern Program (J-1 Visa).docx:
U.S. Intern Program (J-1 Visa)

Overview

The J-1 Intern Program is designed to enable university students and recent graduates to experience the American workplace and acquire practical skills related to their academic field. The program is not limited to professional training but also aims to foster cultural exchange by integrating interns into American society, offering a comprehensive professional and cultural experience.

Program Duration: From 3 weeks up to 12 months.

Target Group: Currently enrolled full-time university students outside the U.S., or recent graduates within the last 12 months.

Available Fields: Business, Management, Engineering, Tourism & Hospitality, Media, Arts, Science, Law, Education, and others.

Permitted Activities

Practical training in the academic field of specialization.

Participation in professional projects within American companies.

Attending workshops and cultural activities to enhance cultural exchange.

Not permitted to work outside the scope of the training specified in the Training Plan (DS-7002).

Essential Requirements

The applicant must be a currently enrolled full-time university student outside the U.S., or a recent graduate within the last 12 months.

Proficiency in English at a level enabling communication in a work environment.

Obtaining an official internship offer from a U.S. company or institution.

Having an accredited Sponsor from the U.S. Department of State to issue Form DS-2019.

A valid passport for the entire duration of the program.

Application Steps

Obtain an internship offer from a U.S. company.

Prepare and sign Form DS-7002 (Training Plan).

Receive Form DS-2019 from the sponsoring organization.

Pay the SEVIS I-901 fee ($220 USD).

Complete the DS-160 online application form.

Pay the visa fee ($185 USD).

Book an appointment at the U.S. Embassy.

Attend the interview and submit documents.

Required Documents for the Interview

Visa Application Form (DS-160).

Form DS-2019 issued by the sponsor.

Signed Training Plan Form (DS-7002) from the host company.

Visa Fee Receipt ($185 USD).

SEVIS I-901 Fee Receipt ($220 USD).

Recent personal photo (5x5 cm, white background).

Valid Passport.

Acceptance or Internship Offer letter from the U.S. company.

Costs and Fees

Visa Application Fee: USD 185

SEVIS I-901 Fee: USD 220

Program/Sponsor Fees: Vary depending on the sponsoring organization, usually ranging between USD 1,000 â€“ 2,000

Potential Additional Costs:

Document shipping

Translation or credential evaluation

Mandatory health insurance (USD 600â€“1,200 annually)

All fees are non-refundable, even if the application is refused.

Benefits for Jordanian Students

Opportunity to gain practical experience in an American work environment.

Development of professional and linguistic skills.

Enhancing the CV with international experience.

A rich cultural experience through living and working in the United States.

Building a global professional network.

What Kaya Offers You

Assisting you in selecting the most suitable company or training field.

Professional preparation of your academic and professional file.

Follow-up on all application steps until the visa is issued.

Training you for the personal interview at the Embassy.

Start your global career path with Kaya â€” Register now to be guided step-by-step from the internship offer to receiving your J-1 Intern visa.

files.U.S. College & University Student Progra:
U.S. College & University Student Program (J-1 Visa)

Overview

The J-1 College & University Student Program provides an opportunity for international students to study full-time at accredited U.S. degree-granting institutions or to enroll in student training programs that fulfill their educational goals in their home country. A key requirement for this track is that the funding for studies must be directly or indirectly from a non-personal source (governmental, international, or educational), and must be under agreements between U.S. and foreign entities or via approved funding arrangements, not through personal or family funds.

Eligibility and Program Scope

Full-Time Study: Must enroll in an accredited university program and maintain satisfactory academic progress during the program period.

Study Alternatives: Can participate in a student training program that meets the objectives of your academic curriculum in Jordan if it is part of your approved study plan.

Qualified Funding: Funding must come from the U.S. Government, the Jordanian Government, an international organization, or an educational entity/scholarship, not from personal or family funds.

Participation Method: Must participate through accredited sponsors under the BridgeUSA program, pursuant to agreements between American and foreign educational institutions or via official funding arrangements.

Difference Between J1 Visa and J2 Dependent Visa

J1 (Student): Granted to individuals accepted into an academic program or student training program with eligible non-personal funding. The holder must comply with full-time study requirements and the academic regulations of the institution and sponsor.

J2 (Dependent): Issued to the spouse and unmarried children under 21 years of age. A J2 dependent may apply for a work permit (EAD) after arrival if permitted by the sponsor. Full-time study is generally not allowed except under institutional regulations, though part-time study is often permitted. Work and study restrictions vary depending on sponsor instructions and regulatory guidelines.

Key Advantages for Jordanian Students

Educational Quality Mark: Studying at accredited degree-granting universities increases your competitiveness in the regional and global job market.

Institutional Links: The program relies on official agreements between educational institutions, facilitating academic recognition and accreditation later on.

Goal-Oriented Training: The student training option is integrated with your study plan in Jordan, ensuring a clear educational return.

Non-Personal Funding Opportunities: The program opens alternative funding channels for outstanding students through government or institutional grants.

Requirements and Qualifications

J-1 College & University Student Specific Eligibility

Non-Personal Funding: Direct or indirect funding from the U.S. Government, the Jordanian Government, an international organization, or an educational institution/agreement; personal/family funding is not eligible.

Formal Agreement/Arrangement: Participation must be based on a formal agreement between a U.S. institution and your home institution or a governmental/educational body; or under government-to-government agreements.

Full-Time Engagement: Must pursue accredited university study or student training linked to your study goals in Jordan with satisfactory academic progress.

Academic Admission Requirements (University/College)

Accredited University Acceptance: Acceptance letter from an accredited, degree-granting U.S. institution.

Language Requirements: TOEFL or IELTS scores as required by the program, or specific waivers based on agreements.

Academic Record: Transcripts, secondary/bachelor's/master's degrees depending on the study level, and letters of recommendation if required.

Financial Capability: Proof of sufficient funding as per the grant/agreement letter, and any supporting documents required by the sponsor.

These requirements vary by university and program. Consult the specific admission guidelines for each institution to determine the required scores and documents.

Application Steps

Obtain Acceptance and Qualified Funding: Through an institutional agreement or government/international grant, not personal funds.

Obtain DS-2019 from the Sponsor: After verifying eligibility and funding.

Pay the SEVIS I-901 Fee: And link it to your SEVIS record.

Complete the DS-160 and Pay the J Visa Fee: Via the designated platform.

Book the Consular Interview Appointment: And prepare the necessary documents.

Attend the Interview and Submit Documents: Answering clearly about the program goals and funding.

Decision and Visa Collection: Then finalize travel and accommodation arrangements.

Remember that travel regulations may impose a specific time frame for arrival before the program starts, according to sponsor and university instructions.

Required Documents

Before the Visa Application

Form DS-2019: Issued by the Sponsor after your acceptance and verification of qualified funding.

SEVIS I-901 Fee: Must be paid after DS-2019 issuance and before the visa application.

Valid Passport: Must be valid for at least 6 months beyond the program end date.

University Acceptance/Training Arrangement: Acceptance letter or student training documentation linked to your academic plan.

Funding Documentation: Letters of non-personal, accredited grant/funding agreements, as per program requirements.

During the Embassy Interview

DS-160 Form: Completed online.

Visa Fee Receipt: For the J category.

Original DS-2019 Form: Issued by the sponsor.

Proof of SEVIS I-901 Payment.

Personal Photo: U.S. specifications (5x5 cm, white background).

Supporting Documents (Non-mandatory): Acceptance letters, academic transcript, language proficiency proof, and official funding documentation.

Important Policies and Considerations

Mandatory Health Insurance: J-1 programs require health insurance coverage meeting specific minimum standards for the entire program duration; this is determined by the sponsor and aligns with Department of State regulations.

Two-Year Home Country Physical Presence Requirement (212(e)): May apply to some J-1 participants if funding is governmental or the specialization is on the Skills List; this may necessitate returning to Jordan for two years before certain status changes. Consult the sponsor to confirm if the requirement applies to you.

Work and Training: Only activities within the program's framework are allowed (e.g., integrated academic student training), and any work must be with the sponsor's approval and J regulations.

J-2 Dependents: Can apply for an Employment Authorization Document (EAD) after arrival, subject to regulations and the sponsor; part-time study policies vary by institution.

These points are organized within the Exchange Visitor Program framework and have implementation details determined by accredited sponsors.

Costs and Fees

When applying for the J-1/J-2 Exchange Visitor Visas (College & University Student), there are key fees the student must be aware of for correct financial planning:

Visa Application Fee (MRV): $185 USD per applicant (both J-1 student and J-2 dependent).

SEVIS I-901 Student System Fee: $220 USD for the J-1 student, payable after the DS-2019 is issued and before the consular interview (J-2 dependents are exempt).

University Application Fee: Varies by institution and program, usually between $50 â€“ $200 USD, paid separately from the visa and SEVIS fees.

Potential Additional Costs:

Shipping acceptance documents via courier (DHL, FedEx, etc.).

Fees for document translation or credential evaluation if required by the university.

Mandatory Health Insurance compliant with U.S. Department of State standards, which may range from $600 â€“ $1,200 annually.

Service fees if using an agency or intermediary.

Important Notes:

All fees are non-refundable, even if the application is refused.

Admission and study costs vary based on the university and agreements signed with educational institutions.

Student records are managed via the SEVIS system according to official instructions, making fee payment an essential, non-negotiable step.

Why Kaya is Your Best Choice

Funding and Agreement Eligibility Confirmation: We review funding sources and contracts to ensure they meet J-1 requirements, avoiding application refusal.

Coordination with Sponsor and University: To ensure smooth DS-2019 issuance and adherence to SEVIS and interview deadlines.

Professional Interview Preparation: We design a clear file for you explaining the program goals and its link to your study plan in Jordan.

J-2 Dependent Support: Guidance on documentation and work/study options according to regulations.

Practical Advice for Jordanian Students

Start with Institutional Funding: Seek Jordanian government grants, joint university agreements, or funded international programsâ€”this is the foundation for your acceptance into the J-1 College & University Student track.

Document Your Educational Goals: Directly link your program in America to your study plan in Jordan to ensure training or coursework consistency with program regulations.

Commit to Academic Progress: Maintain full-time enrollment and satisfactory performance, as this is an essential condition for remaining in the program.

Start your academic journey in the United States with Kaya â€” Register now and let us guide you step-by-step from acceptance to receiving your J-1 visa, to confidently build your future.

files.U.S. Teacher Program (J-1 Visa).docx:
U.S. Teacher Program (J-1 Visa)

Overview

The J-1 Teacher Program is an initiative by the U.S. Department of State under the BridgeUSA umbrella. It aims to promote cultural and educational exchange by bringing qualified international teachers to teach in American schools (elementary, middle, and high schools). This program offers Jordanian teachers the opportunity to teach full-time in accredited U.S. schools for up to 3 years, with the possibility of a two-year extension (maximum of 5 years).

Permitted Activities

Teaching academic subjects in U.S. schools (K-12).

Participating in school activities and community events to enhance cultural exchange.

Developing teaching skills through practical training and interaction with advanced educational systems.

Contributing to curriculum enrichment by introducing teaching perspectives and experiences from Jordan.

Essential Requirements

The applicant must hold at least a Bachelor's degree in education or the subject they will teach.

A minimum of two years of full-time teaching experience.

English proficiency at a level enabling teaching in an American environment (TOEFL or IELTS may be required).

Obtaining a job offer from an accredited U.S. school through an approved Sponsor from the U.S. Department of State.

A valid passport for the entire duration of the program.

Application Steps

Apply through an accredited sponsor and secure a job offer from a U.S. school.

Receive Form DS-2019 from the sponsoring organization.

Pay the SEVIS I-901 fee ($220 USD).

Complete the DS-160 online application form.

Pay the visa fee ($185 USD).

Book an appointment at the U.S. Embassy in Amman.

Attend the personal interview and submit the required documents.

Receive the visa and travel to the United States.

Required Documents for the Interview

Completed visa application form DS-160.

Form DS-2019 issued by the sponsoring organization.

Visa Fee Receipt ($185 USD).

SEVIS I-901 Fee Receipt ($220 USD).

Recent personal photo (5x5 cm, white background).

Valid Passport.

Academic Qualification Certificates (Bachelor's or higher).

Proof of Teaching Experience (experience letters or employment contracts).

Costs and Fees

Visa Application Fee: USD 185 per applicant.

SEVIS I-901 Fee: USD 220 for the J1 teacher.

Program/Sponsor Fees: Vary depending on the sponsoring organization and may include:

Initial processing fee (up to USD 1,500)

Mandatory health insurance (approximately USD 95â€“140 per month)

Potential Additional Costs:

Document shipping

Translation or credential evaluation

Personal expenses

All fees are non-refundable, even if the application is refused.

The Two-Year Home Country Requirement (212(e))

Some teachers may be subject to the requirement to return to their home country for two consecutive years after the program ends, especially if the funding is governmental or if the specialization is on the Skills List. A Waiver can be requested in special cases, such as obtaining a No Objection Statement from the Jordanian Government.

Benefits for Jordanian Teachers

Opportunity to teach in an advanced educational environment.

Developing teaching skills and learning new curricula and methodologies.

Enhancing the CV with international experience.

Building a professional and cultural network.

A rich cultural experience through interaction with American society.

What Kaya Offers You

Specialized consultation to select the most suitable sponsor and school.

Professional preparation of your academic and professional file.

Follow-up on all application steps until the visa is issued.

Training you for the personal interview at the Embassy.

Start your educational journey in the United States with Kaya â€” Register now and let us guide you step-by-step from the job offer to receiving your J-1 Teacher visa.

files.Cultural Exchange Visas (J1-J2).docx:
Cultural Exchange Visas (J1-J2)

General Overview

Your gateway to an American experience rich in knowledge, work, and global networking starts here. The J1â€“J2 visas are specifically designed to promote cultural and educational exchange between the United States and the rest of the world. These programs offer students, researchers, trainees, and professors the opportunity to participate in temporary experiences within the US.

J1 Visa: For primary participants in exchange programs.

J2 Visa: For family members (spouse and unmarried children under 21 years of age).

Available Programs

Cultural exchange programs in the United States include 16 main categories, designed to meet the needs of students, academics, professionals, and families seeking an educational and cultural experience. Hereâ€™s an overview of each program:

Summer Work Travel 

The most popular among university students, combining seasonal work with travel during the summer break. Learn more.

Camp Counselor

 Work as a supervisor in American summer camps, combining leadership, fun, and building global friendships. Learn more.

Trainee 

Designed for young professionals to gain advanced practical experience in their fields within a U.S. work environment. Learn more.

Intern 

A practical program for students and recent graduates, offering professional training within American companies and institutions. Learn more.

College & University Student 

Enroll in academic or research courses at U.S. universities, with opportunities to exchange knowledge and engage in campus life. Learn more.

Secondary School Student 

Allows younger students to study in American schools and live with host families to experience U.S. culture firsthand. Learn more.

Research Scholar 

For researchers to participate in scientific or academic projects within U.S. universities and research centers. Learn more.

Professor 

Provides opportunities for university professors to teach or participate in academic programs in the United States. Learn more.

Teacher 

Enables teachers to teach in American schools for a set period, enhancing educational and cultural exchange. Learn more.

Physician 

For doctors seeking training or participation in advanced medical programs within U.S. hospitals. Learn more.

Au Pair 

Allows young people to live with an American family as household assistants, with opportunities to learn the language and engage in daily life. Learn more.

International Visitor 

A short-term program aimed at fostering mutual understanding between future leaders from different countries and the United States. Learn more.

Government Visitor 

For government officials or public figures to participate in cultural and political exchange programs. Learn more.

Specialist 

A short-term program for experts and specialists to share knowledge and skills in specific fields. Learn more.

Short-Term Scholar 

For professors and researchers to participate in lectures, workshops, or short-term research projects. Learn more.

STEM Initiatives 

Modern programs focusing on supporting academic and research exchange in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Learn more.



Note: Each program has specific requirements that differ from others. Please review the details of each program separately to learn about all the specific conditions and requirements.

Why Choose J1-J2 Cultural Exchange Visas?

Educational and professional experience in an advanced American environment.

Authentic cultural exchange that opens doors to new lifestyles.

Temporary training and work opportunities in multiple fields.

The possibility of family accompaniment via the J2 visa.

Building an international network that enhances your academic and professional path.

Application Steps

Obtain acceptance from an accredited exchange program.

Receive Form DS-2019 from the sponsoring organization.

Pay the SEVIS fee.

Complete the DS-160 form and pay the visa fee.

Schedule an appointment at the US Embassy or Consulate.

Attend the personal interview and submit documents.

Receive the visa and embark on your American experience.

Required Documents

(May vary depending on the chosen program)

DS-160 Visa Application Form confirmation page.

Form DS-2019 from the sponsoring organization.

Payment receipts for the Visa Fee and SEVIS Fee.

Recent personal photos (5x5 cm size, white background).

A letter explaining the purpose of participation.

Supporting documents (university acceptance, training contract, or official invitation).

Official Fees

Visa Application Fee: USD 185 per applicant (whether J1 for the participant or J2 for the dependent).

SEVIS I-901 Fee: USD 220 for the primary participant (J1). No SEVIS fee is charged for dependents (J2).

Fees may vary or be waived in some programs. Local costs (such as courier services or appointment fees) may also be added.

What Kaya Offers You

Assistance in choosing the most suitable program for your path.

Professional preparation of your academic and professional file.

Follow-up on all application steps until the visa is issued.

Additional support for your family in case of J2 visa application.

Live an unforgettable cultural exchange experience with Kaya â€” from program acceptance to your arrival in the United States, we are your partner every step of the way.

files.United States of America Visas.docx:
United States of America Visas

Overview

The United States of America (USA) is one of the world's largest and most significant nations, comprising 50 states extending from the Atlantic Ocean in the East to the Pacific Ocean in the West. Founded in 1776 after the Declaration of Independence, the US is today a leading global power in economy, education, technology, and culture.

America is known as the land of dreams, where investment and educational opportunities are diverse, attracting millions of visitors and students annually. It is home to the most prestigious universities worldwide, such as Harvard, MIT, and Stanford University, in addition to prominent tourist attractions like the Statue of Liberty, the White House, the Grand Canyon, and Disneyland, among others.

The US is also a source of various cultures and arts that have influenced the world and offers diverse programs for immigration, investment, and study, making it a primary destination for those aspiring to build a better future.

Why Should You Travel to the United States of America?

Traveling to America means opening up to a world of unlimited opportunities. It is a destination that combines prestigious education at the world's most elite universities with economic opportunities that open doors for ambitious entrepreneurs and professionals. For visitors, America presents an exceptional experience blending cultural diversity that enriches the mind and unparalleled tourist landmarks like New York, Los Angeles, and the Grand Canyon.

Furthermore, the United States provides an ideal environment for those wishing to develop their professional skills or explore new markets, with a diverse community that welcomes visitors from all over the world. Whether you seek an unforgettable tourist trip, an educational opportunity that opens future horizons, or a work experience that adds to your professional value, America grants you all this and more.

Types of US Visas

US visas are divided into two main categories:

1. Immigrant Visas

Intended for those seeking permanent residence in the United States and obtaining a Green Card.

Family Reunification: The most common path, where US citizens and permanent residents can sponsor their spouses, children, or parents.

Employment-Based Visas: Granted to highly skilled individuals or investors who contribute to the US economy.

Diversity Visa Lottery (DV Lottery): Annually grants thousands of individuals from different countries the opportunity to obtain permanent residency.

After obtaining a Green Card, one can later apply for US citizenship.

2. Non-Immigrant Visas

Intended for those seeking temporary travel for specific purposes such as tourism, study, work, or medical treatment.

Key Non-Immigrant Visas

Tourism, Visit, and Medical Treatment Visas (B1-B2) Granted to individuals wishing to visit the United States for tourism, short business trips, or medical treatment. 

For full details, click here.

Academic Study Visas (F1-F2) Designed for students seeking to enroll in U.S. universities, also granted to accompanying family members. 

For full details, click here.

Vocational Study Visas (M1-M2) Issued to students pursuing vocational or technical studies at specialized institutes in the United States. 

For full details, click here.

Cultural Exchange Visas (J1-J2) Intended for educational, training, and cultural exchange programs, also covering accompanying family members. 

For full details, click here.

Specialized Work Visa (H1B) Granted to professionals in specific fields to work for U.S. companies for a limited period of time. 

For full details, click here.

Temporary Work Visa (H2B) For seasonal or temporary employment in sectors such as tourism, agriculture, and services. 

For full details, click here.

files.Student Visa for the USA (F-1 Visa).docx:
Student Visa for the USA (F-1 Visa)

Why Choose America for Study?

Global Academic Hub: Home to the world's top universities like Harvard, MIT, and Stanford.

Vast Cultural Diversity: Hosts over a million international students annually.

Innovation Powerhouse: Strength in scientific research and innovation with massive funding and advanced research opportunities.

Vibrant Campus Life: Bursting with activities, student associations, and cultural events.

Available Programs

English as a Second Language Institutes (ESL).

Diploma, Bachelor's, Master's, and Doctoral degrees.

Conditional Admission: University acceptance conditional upon completing a language program.

Estimated Costs

Tuition Fees:

Starting from USD 10,000 per year at some community colleges

Up to USD 80,000 per year at prestigious private universities (e.g., Medicine, Engineering)

Average: USD 25,000â€“45,000 per year for most undergraduate programs

Living Expenses:

Between USD 1,500â€“3,000 per month depending on the city (New York and Boston higher, smaller cities lower)

Includes housing, food, transportation, and health insurance

Most In-Demand Majors

Information Technology and Computer Science.

Business Administration and Finance.

Medicine and Engineering.

Marketing and Social Sciences.

Student Life

Major Student Cities: Boston (University City), New York (Global Business Center), California (Innovation and Technology).

Diverse Campus Activities: Student associations, university sports, and cultural/artistic events.

Cultural Diversity: Over one million international students create a multinational environment.

Work Opportunities During and After Study

During Study

On-Campus Employment: Permitted up to 20 hours per week during the academic semester, and full-time during vacations.

CPT (Curricular Practical Training):

A program that allows work or internships directly related to the academic major.

Can be on or off-campus but requires university authorization.

After Graduation

OPT (Optional Practical Training):

Temporary work authorization for 12 months after graduation.

For STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) students, it can be extended up to 3 years.

Transition to Work Visa (H-1B): A common option for staying and working after OPT concludes.

Essential Steps for US Student Visa Application (F-1)

Obtain university admission and Form I-20 from a certified educational institution.

Pay the SEVIS fee ($350) and register your data in the system.

Complete the electronic DS-160 form via the embassy website.

Pay the Visa Fee ($185).

Schedule an interview appointment at the US Embassy or Consulate.

Attend the interview with all required documents (passport, I-20, financial proof, photos, TOEFL/IELTS results).

Await the visa decision and receive your passport with the visa stamp.

Detailed Explanation of Steps

1. University Acceptance & Form I-20: You must first apply to an accredited US university or institute. Upon acceptance, the institution will send you Form I-20, which proves your enrollment and is essential for the visa application.

2. Pay the SEVIS Fee: SEVIS is a database for international students. You pay the fee ($350) online and receive a receipt that must be presented at the interview.

3. Complete the DS-160 Form: An electronic form on the US Embassy website. After filling it out, print the confirmation page with the barcode.

4. Pay the Visa Fee ($185): Paid through a bank or online, according to the embassy's instructions in your country.

5. Schedule the Interview: Done via the embassy or visa center website. It is advisable to book early due to potential high demand.

6. Attend the Interview: The most critical stage, where the Consular Officer assesses your academic intent and financial capability. You must demonstrate that you intend to return to your home country after your studies and have sufficient funding.

7. Visa Collection: If approved, your passport will be stamped with the F-1 visa. You can enter the US up to 30 days before your program start date.

Golden Tips for Success

Prepare clear answers regarding why you chose the US and your major.

Highlight your future plans after returning to your home country.

Ensure your financial documents show a genuine ability to cover the costs.

Be confident and calm during the interview.

Required Documents for Submission

Valid passport.

Acceptance letter from a certified university/institute (I-20).

Financial proof covering tuition and living expenses.

Completed Visa Application Form (DS-160).

Payment receipts for the SEVIS fee ($350) and the Visa Fee ($185).

Passport-compliant personal photos.

Proof of English proficiency (TOEFL/IELTS).

Appointment confirmation for the interview.

With Kaya: Your Path to America is Easier

We help you choose the right university based on your budget and major.

Preparation of a complete, error-free visa file.

Support in proving financial capability and drafting the Statement of Intent.

Post-arrival follow-up: Registration, housing, and initial job opportunities.

With Kaya, every country is a new opportunity for a rich educational and life experience, and we accompany you step-by-step until you reach your dream.

files.Canada Study Permit.docx:
Canada Study Permit

Why Choose Canada?

World-Class Universities: Home to prestigious universities such as the University of Toronto, McGill University, and the University of British Columbia (UBC).

High Quality, Lower Cost: Lower costs compared to the UK and the US, while maintaining high educational quality.

Bilingual Advantage: A bilingual country (English and French) giving you an added advantage.

Post-Graduation Opportunities: Clear pathways to employment and immigration through programs like the Post-Graduation Work Permit (PGWP) and Express Entry.

Safe and Diverse Community: A safe and welcoming society that hosts over 600,000 international students annually.

Estimated Costs

Tuition Fees: CAD 13,000â€“25,000 per year (depending on the program)

Living Expenses: CAD 10,000â€“15,000 per year (depending on the city)

Study Permit Fee: CAD 150

Health Insurance: Varies by province (some include students, others require private insurance)

Application Steps

Obtain university admission from a Designated Learning Institution (DLI).

Prepare and translate all documents into English or French.

Apply via the IRCC website or a local Visa Application Centre (VAC).

Pay the fees and book an appointment for Biometrics.

Wait for the decision (usually 6â€“12 weeks).

Detailed Required Documents

Valid passport + recent personal photos.

Letter of Acceptance (LOA) from a Designated Learning Institution (DLI).

Proof of Financial Support covering:

Tuition fees for the first year.

Living expenses ($10,000 CAD per year for the student, + $4,000 for the first dependent).

Travel tickets.

Academic certificates (high school/university) translated and authenticated.

Language Proficiency Proof: IELTS/TOEFL for English or TEF for French (depending on the program language).

Study Permit Application Form via the Canadian immigration website (IRCC).

Application Fee: $150 CAD.

Health Insurance documentation (Mandatory).

Police Clearance Certificate (may be requested depending on your country of residence).

Quebec Acceptance Certificate (CAQ): If studying in the province of Quebec.

Statement of Purpose (SOP): Explaining your reasons for choosing Canada and your future plans.

Important Details

Letter of Acceptance and Deposit

To obtain a study permit, you must have an LOA from a DLI. Some universities issue a conditional acceptance upon payment of an initial fee installment.

Advance Payment (Deposit)

The deposit is often between $500 â€“ $2,000 CAD as a reservation fee to secure your seat.

Some universities require the payment of the first tuition installment (which may equal a full semester) before issuing the final LOA.

Purpose of Advance Payment:

Proves seriousness of enrollment.

Ensures the student has the financial capacity to cover studies.

Used as part of the proof of funds when applying for the study permit.

Variation by Institution: Major universities like the University of Toronto or McGill often require a partial advance payment. Some colleges and institutes (especially in Quebec or language programs) may require the full tuition to be paid before acceptance is issued.

âš ï¸ Key Notes

The Canadian government does not mandate advance tuition payment as a visa condition, but it requires proof of financial capability. Universities set their own policies.

Paying part of the tuition in advance strengthens your study permit application as it shows you have already started covering your costs.

Beware of unaccredited institutes: The institution must be on the Designated Learning Institutions (DLI) list, otherwise, the study permit will not be accepted.

Work Opportunities During and After Study

During Study

Allowed to work 20 hours per week during the academic semester.

Full-time work during scheduled breaks.

After Graduation

Via the Post-Graduation Work Permit (PGWP), you can stay and work for up to 3 years.

This work experience helps you apply for permanent residency through Canadian immigration programs.

Student Life in Canada

Major Cities: Toronto (global and diverse), Vancouver (stunning nature), Montreal (French and English culture), Ottawa (quiet and organized capital).

University Activities: Student clubs, winter sports (skiing and hockey), music and cultural festivals.

Cultural Diversity: Canada is one of the top immigrant-receiving countries, creating an inclusive and multinational environment for students.

Support Services: Universities provide support offices for international students, academic advising, and housing services.

With Kaya: Your Path to Canada is Easier

We help you choose the right university and program.

Professional preparation of a complete, error-free visa file.

Support in proving financial capability and health insurance.

Post-arrival follow-up: Registration, housing, and initial job opportunities.

With Kaya, every country is a new opportunity for a rich educational and life experience, and we accompany you step-by-step until you reach your dream.

files.UK Student Visa.docx:
UK Student Visa

The United Kingdom is one of the most attractive destinations for international students, thanks to its ancient universities like Oxford and Cambridge, its diverse academic programs, and its post-graduation work opportunities.

Why Choose the UK?

World-Class Universities: Over 100 universities are featured in international rankings.

Shorter Study Duration: Bachelor's degrees typically take 3 years, and Master's degrees are often one year.

Post-Graduation Work Opportunities: Through the Graduate Route visa, which grants you two years to stay and work (3 years for PhD graduates).

Multicultural Environment: Over 500,000 international students annually.

Work Opportunities During and After Study

During Study

University and postgraduate students are allowed to work 20 hours per week during the academic semester.

Full-time work is permitted during official holidays.

Students in English language programs are usually limited to 10 hours per week.

Common Job Types: Working in restaurants, cafes, and retail stores; assistant jobs in universities (libraries, administrative support); private tutoring or academic assistance; event and festival work.

After Graduation

Through the Graduate Route Visa, you can stay and work in the UK for two years (or three years for PhD graduates).

This allows you to gain professional experience and connect your studies to the British job market.

Student Life in the UK

Vibrant Student Cities:

London: A global center for culture, arts, and business, but the highest in cost.

Manchester: A major city for music and sports, with lower costs than London.

Oxford and Cambridge: Historic academic atmosphere and strong student communities.

Edinburgh and Glasgow: Scottish cities that combine history and nature.

University Activities:

Student societies covering every interest (cultural, sports, professional).

Sports clubs, from football to rowing.

Cultural events, music festivals, and theater performances throughout the year.

Cultural Diversity:

Over half a million international students annually.

A multinational environment that provides you with a global network.

Estimated Costs

Tuition Fees: Usually range between GBP 11,000â€“25,000 per year for international students, with significantly higher costs for medical and engineering programs.

Living Expenses (visa requirements):

Outside London: GBP 1,023 per month

Inside London: GBP 1,334 per month (These figures represent the minimum funds that must be demonstrated when applying for a visa.)

Visa Fees:

Applying from outside the UK: approx. GBP 490

Applying from inside the UK (extension or change): slightly higher (GBP 490â€“600)

Other types also exist, such as Short-term Study Visa or Child Student Visa, with different fees.

Health Insurance (Immigration Health Surcharge â€“ IHS): Currently GBP 776 per year for students. The full amount must be paid upfront based on visa duration (e.g., 3 years = GBP 2,328).

Application Steps

Obtain university admission (CAS - Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies).

Prepare and translate documents into English.

Apply via the UK Immigration website.

Pay the fees + IHS.

Book an appointment for Biometrics.

Wait for the decision (usually 3â€“8 weeks).

Detailed Required Documents

Passport and Photos: A valid passport covering the study period and recent personal photos meeting UK visa standards.

Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies (CAS): A reference number issued by the UK university after your acceptance. It includes program details, fees, and study dates.

Financial Proof: Bank statement covering:

Tuition fees for the first year (or the entire program if less than a year).

Maintenance funds (Â£1,023 or Â£1,334 monthly, depending on the university's location).

The funds must have been held in the account for 28 consecutive days before the application date.

English Language Proficiency: IELTS Academic, TOEFL, or equivalent certificates. Some universities may exempt you if you have previously studied in English.

Academic Certificates: High school/Bachelor's/Master's certificates (depending on the program), translated and authenticated.

IHS Payment: Proof of payment for the Immigration Health Surcharge to access NHS healthcare.

Application Form and Fees: Completed online application and electronic fee payment.

Police Clearance Certificate (May be requested): Especially if the study duration exceeds 6 months.

Upon Arrival

Register at the university.

Collect your Biometric Residence Permit (BRP).

Open a local bank account.

Ability to work 20 hours per week during study.

With Kaya: Your Path to the UK is Easier

We help you choose the right program.

Professional preparation of a complete, error-free visa file.

Support in proving financial capability and health insurance.

Post-arrival follow-up: BRP, housing, and initial job opportunities.

With Kaya, every country is a new opportunity for a rich educational and life experience, and we accompany you step-by-step until you reach your dream.

files.Australia Student Visa (Subclass 500).do:
Australia Student Visa (Subclass 500)

Australia is one of the world's leading educational destinations, thanks to its top-ranked universities, its multicultural environment, and the possibility of working while studying.

Why Choose Australia?

Top Global Universities: Universities ranked within the top 100 worldwide (e.g., Melbourne, Sydney, ANU).

Diverse Programs: Bachelor's, Master's, PhD, and Vocational Education and Training (VET) courses.

English Language: An ideal opportunity to improve your academic and professional English.

Student Work Opportunities: Up to 48 hours of work per fortnight during the study period.

Vibrant Student Life: Major cities like Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, and Adelaide.

Work Opportunities During and After Study

During Study

International students are allowed to work up to 48 hours per fortnight (approximately 24 hours per week).

Full-time work is permitted during official academic breaks/holidays.

Work is not permitted before the student's course officially commences.

Common Job Types: Hospitality (restaurants, cafes, hotels), Retail (shops, malls), Healthcare and Community support (for those with experience), Private tutoring, On-campus jobs (libraries, administration).

After Graduation

Through the Temporary Graduate Visa (Subclass 485), you can stay and work in Australia for 2 to 4 years (depending on your qualification).

This allows you to gain professional experience and connect your studies to the Australian job market.

Student Life in Australia

Major Student Cities:

Sydney: Global city, stunning beaches, wide job opportunities.

Melbourne: Culture and arts capital, vibrant student environment.

Brisbane: Lower costs, warmer weather, diverse student community.

Adelaide and Perth: Smaller, quieter cities with lower living costs.

University Activities:

Student clubs covering sports, arts, technology, and culture.

Music events and local festivals.

Sports activities such as surfing, football, and rugby.

Cultural Diversity:

Australia hosts over 700,000 international students annually.

A multinational environment that provides you with a global network.

Estimated Costs (AUD - Australian Dollars)

Tuition Fees: $15,000 â€“ $35,000 AUD annually (depending on the major).

Living Expenses: $1,500 â€“ $2,200 AUD monthly.

Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC): Mandatory for the entire duration of stay.

Application Steps

Select the program and university and obtain the Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE).

Prepare and translate documents into English.

Apply via the Australian Department of Home Affairs website (ImmiAccount).

Pay the fees and book an appointment for Biometrics and a medical examination.

Wait for the decision (usually 4â€“8 weeks).

Upon Arrival

Register at the university.

Activate the OSHC (Health Insurance).

Open a local bank account.

Obtain a Tax File Number (TFN) for legal part-time work.

Required Documents

Passport and Photos: A valid passport covering the study period and recent personal photos with a white background.

Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE): Issued by an accredited Australian university/institute, detailing the program, duration, and fees.

Financial Proof: Bank statement covering:

Tuition fees.

Living expenses (approximately $24,505 AUD annually for the student).

Travel tickets.

Alternatively, financial sponsorship from a guardian/sponsor.

Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC): Mandatory for all international students, covering treatment, emergencies, and basic medications.

Academic Certificates: High school/Bachelor's/Master's certificates (depending on the program), translated and authenticated.

English Language Proficiency: Typically IELTS 6.0â€“6.5, or TOEFL, or PTE.

Visa Application Form and Fee: Complete the online Student Visa Subclass 500 application and pay the fee (approx. $710 AUD).

Police Clearance Certificate: To prove a clean criminal record.

Medical Certificate (May be requested): A medical examination certified by the Australian embassy/consulate.

With Kaya: Your Path to Australia is Easier

We help you choose the right program.

Professional preparation of a complete, error-free visa file.

Support with health insurance and accommodation.

Post-arrival follow-up: Registration, bank account, and first job opportunity.

With Kaya, every country is a new opportunity for a rich educational and life experience, and we accompany you step-by-step until you reach your dream.

files.Germany Student Visa.docx:
Germany Student Visa

Germany is not only an economic power but also an educational powerhouse. Its universities are among the best globally, offering you the opportunity to combine top-tier academic education with vast career opportunities in the heart of Europe.

Why Choose Germany?

Near-Free Education: Most public universities do not charge tuition fees, apart from a symbolic semester contribution (â‚¬200â€“â‚¬400).

High Academic Quality: Globally ranked universities, especially strong in Engineering, Medicine, and Applied Sciences.

Extensive Work Opportunities: Right to work 120 full days or 240 half days annually alongside studies.

Strategic Location: The heart of Europe, making travel to EU countries easy.

Rich Student Life: Cities like Berlin, Munich, Heidelberg, and Cologne combine history and modernity.

Available Programs

Bachelor's, Master's, and Doctoral degrees in various disciplines.

Preparatory Language Programs (Studienkolleg): For students who need to equate their high school certificates.

English-Taught Programs: Especially common at the Master's level, alongside German-taught programs.

Estimated Costs

Tuition Fees: Free or symbolic (EUR 200â€“400 per semester)

Monthly Living Expenses: EUR 850â€“1,100 (housing, food, insurance, transportation)

Blocked Account Requirement: Approximately EUR 11,208 (2025) must be deposited to cover one full year

Most In-Demand Majors

Engineering (in its various branches).

Medicine and Life Sciences.

Business Administration and Economics.

Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence.

Application Steps for the Germany Student Visa

Phase 1: University Admission

Choose your program and university via platforms like DAAD.

Submit your application with: academic certificates, CV, motivation letter, and language certificate.

Obtain either direct university admission or conditional admission (if you require a language course or Studienkolleg).

Phase 2: Visa File Preparation

Visa application form + signature.

Valid passport and recent biometric photos.

University admission letter.

Proof of financial resources: Blocked Account or official guarantee letter (VerpflichtungserklÃ¤rung).

Student health insurance.

Academic certificates (translated and authenticated).

CV + Motivation Letter.

Language certificate: German (TestDaF/DSH) or English (IELTS/TOEFL).

Police clearance certificate (may be required depending on the consulate).

Medical certificate (in some cases).

Phase 3: Application Submission

Book an appointment at the German Embassy/Consulate.

Pay the visa fee (approximately â‚¬75).

Attend the personal interview to explain your study plan.

Upon Arrival in Germany

Register at the university.

Obtain the Student Residence Permit (Aufenthaltstitel) from the Foreigners' Office within 90 days.

Open a local bank account and activate the blocked account.

Register at the local city hall (Anmeldung).

Required Documents

Passport + Biometric Photos

Valid passport covering the study period + 6 additional months

Copies of main pages (data and previous visas)

Two recent biometric photos with white background, according to German embassy standards

University Admission Letter or Conditional Admission

Direct admission from a German university

Or conditional admission (if language study or Studienkolleg is required)

The letter must specify: program name, duration, language of instruction, and start date

Proof of Financial Means

Blocked Account: approx. EUR 11,208 (2025) deposited to cover one full year

Or Official Guarantee (VerpflichtungserklÃ¤rung): provided by a resident in Germany committing to cover expenses

Health Insurance

Comprehensive student health insurance covering the entire stay

May start with private insurance before arrival, then switch to public student insurance after university enrollment

Academic Certificates

High school / Bachelorâ€™s / Masterâ€™s certificates (depending on program)

Must be translated into German or English and certified by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the German consulate

Curriculum Vitae (CV) + Motivation Letter

Updated CV showing education, experience, and skills

Motivation letter explaining reasons for choosing Germany, the program, and future plans

Language Certificate

German: TestDaF, DSH, or Goethe-Zertifikat (depending on university requirements)

English: IELTS or TOEFL for programs taught in English

Visa Application Form + Fees

Completed National Visa Application Form

Signed by the student (or guardian if underage)

Visa fee: approx. EUR 75

Police Clearance / Medical Certificate

Police clearance from country of residence (may be required depending on consulate)

Medical certificate proving absence of infectious diseases (required in some cases)

Important Notes:

Translation & Authentication: All non-German documents must be translated and authenticated.

Processing Time: Processing usually takes 6â€“12 weeks, so early application is advised.

Post-Arrival: You must obtain the Student Residence Permit (Aufenthaltstitel) within 90 days of entering Germany.

With Kaya: Your Path to Germany is Easier

We help you choose the right program.

Professional preparation of a complete, error-free visa file.

Support with opening the Blocked Account and health insurance.

Post-arrival follow-up: Student residence permit, registration, and first part-time job opportunity.

With Kaya, every country is a new opportunity for a rich educational and life experience, and we accompany you step-by-step until you reach your dream.
